children.name: Foundational Concepts
children.title: Foundational Concepts
children.description: Theories and methods underpinning AI development.

children.name: Machine Learning (ML)
children.title: Machine Learning (ML)
children.description: Algorithms that enable computers to learn from and make predictions or decisions based on data.

children.name: Wait Calculation
children.title: Wait Calculation
children.description: Assessing whether to proceed with projects immediately or wait for future advancements in AI that could offer significant benefits.

children.name: Supervised Learning
children.title: Supervised Learning
children.description: ML approach where models are trained on labeled data to predict outcomes or classify data into categories.

children.name: Unsupervised Learning
children.title: Unsupervised Learning
children.description: Type of ML where algorithms learn patterns from untagged data, without any guidance on what outcomes to predict.

children.name: Semi-Supervised Learning
children.title: Semi-Supervised Learning
children.description: ML approach that uses a combination of a small amount of labeled data and a large amount of unlabeled data for training models.

children.name: RL (Reinforcement Learning)
children.title: RL (Reinforcement Learning)
children.description: Type of ML where an agent learns to make decisions by performing actions in an environment to achieve a goal, guided by rewards.

children.name: Transfer Learning
children.title: Transfer Learning
children.description: ML method where a model developed for a task is reused as the starting point for a model on a second task, leveraging the knowledge gained from the first task to improve performance on the second.

children.name: Meta-Learning
children.title: Meta-Learning
children.description: "Learning to learn" involves techniques that enable AI models to learn how to adapt quickly to new tasks with minimal data.

children.name: MTL (Multi-Task Learning)
children.title: MTL (Multi-Task Learning)
children.description: ML approach where a single model is trained simultaneously on multiple related tasks, leveraging commonalities and differences across tasks to improve generalization.

children.name: FSL (Few-Shot Learning)
children.title: FSL (Few-Shot Learning)
children.description: ML approach that enables models to learn and make accurate predictions from a very small dataset.

children.name: ZSL (Zero-Shot Learning)
children.title: ZSL (Zero-Shot Learning)
children.description: ML technique where a model learns to recognize objects, tasks, or concepts it has never seen during training.

children.name: Ensemble Learning
children.title: Ensemble Learning
children.description: ML paradigm where multiple models (often called "weak learners") are trained to solve the same problem and combined to improve the accuracy of predictions.

children.name: Imitation Learning
children.title: Imitation Learning
children.description: AI technique where models learn to perform tasks by mimicking human behavior or strategies demonstrated in training data.

children.name: Bagging
children.title: Bagging
children.description: ML ensemble technique that improves the stability and accuracy of machine learning algorithms by combining multiple models trained on different subsets of the same data set.

children.name: Base Model
children.title: Base Model
children.description: Pre-trained AI model that serves as a starting point for further training or adaptation on specific tasks or datasets.

children.name: Boosting
children.title: Boosting
children.description: ML ensemble technique that combines multiple weak learners to form a strong learner, aiming to improve the accuracy of predictions.

children.name: Regression
children.title: Regression
children.description: Statistical method used in ML to predict a continuous outcome variable based on one or more predictor variables.

children.name: Training
children.title: Training
children.description: Process of teaching a ML model to make accurate predictions or decisions, by adjusting its parameters based on data.

children.name: Fine Tuning
children.title: Fine Tuning
children.description: Method used in ML to adjust the parameters of an already trained model to improve its accuracy on a specific, often smaller, dataset.

children.name: ML (Machine Learning)
children.title: ML (Machine Learning)
children.description: Development of algorithms and statistical models that enable computers to perform tasks without being explicitly programmed for each one.

children.name: Deterministic
children.title: Deterministic
children.description: System or process is one that, given a particular initial state, will always produce the same output or result, with no randomness or unpredictability involved.

children.name: Inference
children.title: Inference
children.description: Process by which a trained neural network applies learned patterns to new, unseen data to make predictions or decisions.

children.name: Neural Networks
children.title: Neural Networks
children.description: Computing systems inspired by biological neural networks, foundational for deep learning.

children.name: ANN (Artificial Neural Networks)
children.title: ANN (Artificial Neural Networks)
children.description: Computing systems inspired by the biological neural networks that constitute animal brains, designed to progressively improve their performance on tasks by considering examples.

children.name: Supervised Classifier
children.title: Supervised Classifier
children.description: Algorithm that, given a set of labeled training data, learns to predict the labels of new, unseen data.

children.name: DL (Deep Learning)
children.title: DL (Deep Learning)
children.description: Subset of machine learning that involves neural networks with many layers, enabling the modeling of complex patterns in data.

children.name: DNN (Deep Neural Networks)
children.title: DNN (Deep Neural Networks)
children.description: Advanced neural network architectures with multiple layers that enable complex pattern recognition and learning from large amounts of data.

children.name: CNN (Convolutional Neural Network)
children.title: CNN (Convolutional Neural Network)
children.description: Deep learning algorithm that can capture spatial hierarchies in data, particularly useful for image and video recognition tasks.

children.name: RNN (Recurrent Neural Network)
children.title: RNN (Recurrent Neural Network)
children.description: Class of neural networks where connections between nodes form a directed graph along a temporal sequence, enabling them to exhibit temporal dynamic behavior for a sequence of inputs.

children.name: LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory)
children.title: LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory)
children.description: Type of recurrent neural network architecture designed to learn long-term dependencies in sequential data.

children.name: FCN (Fully Convolutional Networks)
children.title: FCN (Fully Convolutional Networks)
children.description: Neural network architecture designed specifically for image segmentation tasks, where the goal is to classify each pixel of an image into a category.

children.name: Capsule Networks
children.title: Capsule Networks
children.description: Type of artificial neural network designed to improve the processing of spatial hierarchical information by encoding data into small groups of neurons called capsules.

children.name: GNN (Graph Neural Networks)
children.title: GNN (Graph Neural Networks)
children.description: Nype of neural network designed for processing data represented in graph form, capturing relationships and structure within the data.

children.name: NAS (Neural Architecture Search)
children.title: NAS (Neural Architecture Search)
children.description: Automated process that designs optimal neural network architectures for specific tasks.

children.name: Perceptron
children.title: Perceptron
children.description: Model in neural networks designed to perform binary classification tasks by mimicking the decision-making process of a single neuron.

children.name: Self-Attention
children.title: Self-Attention
children.description: Mechanism in neural networks that allows models to weigh the importance of different parts of the input data differently.

children.name: Sequence Models
children.title: Sequence Models
children.description: Algorithms that predict the next element in a sequence, pivotal for tasks in natural language processing (NLP) such as text generation and translation.

children.name: Logits
children.title: Logits
children.description: Raw, unnormalized outputs of the last layer in a neural network before applying the softmax function in classification tasks.

children.name: SoftMax
children.title: SoftMax
children.description: Function that converts a vector of numerical values into a vector of probabilities, where the probabilities of each value are proportional to the exponentials of the input numbers.

children.name: Stacking
children.title: Stacking
children.description: ML ensemble technique that combines multiple classification or regression models via a meta-classifier or meta-regressor to improve prediction accuracy.

children.name: Pretrained Model
children.title: Pretrained Model
children.description: ML model that has been previously trained on a large dataset and can be fine-tuned or used as is for similar tasks or applications.

children.name: Parameter
children.title: Parameter
children.description: Variable that is internal to the model and whose value is estimated from the training data.

children.name: Numerical Processing
children.title: Numerical Processing
children.description: Algorithms and techniques for handling and analyzing numerical data to extract patterns, make predictions, or understand underlying trends.

children.name: Instantiation
children.title: Instantiation
children.description: Process of creating a specific instance of an abstract concept, algorithm, or data structure, allowing for its practical use and application.

children.name: Probabilistic Models
children.title: Probabilistic Models
children.description: Frameworks that incorporate uncertainty by modeling systems and phenomena as probabilistic processes.

children.name: Bayesian Network
children.title: Bayesian Network
children.description: Graphical model that represents probabilistic relationships among variables using directed acyclic graphs (DAGs).

children.name: VAE (Variational Autoencoders)
children.title: VAE (Variational Autoencoders)
children.description: Class of generative models that use neural networks to encode inputs into a latent space and then decode from this space to reconstruct the input or generate new data that resemble the input data.

children.name: EBM (Energy-Based Model)
children.title: EBM (Energy-Based Model)
children.description: Class of deep learning models that learn to associate lower energy levels with more probable configurations of the input data.

children.name: GFlowNet (Generative Flow Networks)
children.title: GFlowNet (Generative Flow Networks)
children.description: Research direction at the intersection of reinforcement learning, deep generative models, and energy-based probabilistic modeling, aimed at improving generative active learning and unsupervised learning.

children.name: PFGM (Poisson Flow Generative Model)
children.title: PFGM (Poisson Flow Generative Model)
children.description: Generative model that utilizes Poisson processes in its architecture to model and generate complex data distributions.

children.name: MoE (Mixture-of-Experts)
children.title: MoE (Mixture-of-Experts)
children.description: ML framework that divides a complex problem into parts, solved by specialized models (experts), and integrates their solutions.

children.name: Random Walk
children.title: Random Walk
children.description: Mathematical concept representing a path consisting of a succession of random steps on some mathematical space.

children.name: Stochastic
children.title: Stochastic
children.description: Systems or processes that are inherently random, involving variables that are subject to chance.

children.name: SSF (Stochastic Similarity Filter)
children.title: SSF (Stochastic Similarity Filter)
children.description: Moderates GPU usage by skipping processing of similar consecutive input images, thereby improving computational efficiency in real-time image and video generation tasks.

children.name: Causal Inference
children.title: Causal Inference
children.description: Process of determining the cause-and-effect relationship between variables.

children.name: Optimization and Learning
children.title: Optimization and Learning
children.description: Techniques to find the best solution from a set of available options, central to machine learning.

children.name: Gradient Descent
children.title: Gradient Descent
children.description: Optimization algorithm used to find the minimum of a function by iteratively moving towards the steepest descent direction.

children.name: Backpropagation
children.title: Backpropagation
children.description: Algorithm used for training artificial neural networks, crucial for optimizing the weights to minimize error between predicted and actual outcomes.

children.name: Loss Function
children.title: Loss Function
children.description: Quantifies the difference between the predicted values by a model and the actual values, serving as a guide for model optimization.

children.name: Objective Function
children.title: Objective Function
children.description: Objective function used in ML which quantitatively defines the goal of an optimization problem by measuring the performance of a model or solution.

children.name: Hyperparameter
children.title: Hyperparameter
children.description: Configuration settings used to structure ML models, which guide the learning process and are set before training begins.

children.name: Weight
children.title: Weight
children.description: Represents a coefficient for a feature in a model that determines the influence of that feature on the model's predictions.

children.name: Weight Decay
children.title: Weight Decay
children.description: Regularization technique used in training neural networks to prevent overfitting by penalizing large weights.

children.name: Dropout
children.title: Dropout
children.description: Regularization technique used in neural networks to prevent overfitting by randomly omitting a subset of neurons during training.

children.name: Overfitting
children.title: Overfitting
children.description: When a ML model learns the detail and noise in the training data to the extent that it negatively impacts the performance of the model on new data.

children.name: Cross Validation
children.title: Cross Validation
children.description: Statistical method used to estimate the skill of ML models on unseen data by partitioning the original dataset into a training set to train the model and a test set to evaluate it.

children.name: AutoML (Automated Machine Learning)
children.title: AutoML (Automated Machine Learning)
children.description: Streamlines the process of applying ML by automating the tasks of selecting the appropriate algorithms and tuning their hyperparameters.

children.name: Loss Optimization
children.title: Loss Optimization
children.description: Process of adjusting a model's parameters to minimize the difference between the predicted outputs and the actual outputs, measured by a loss function.

children.name: Optimization Problem
children.title: Optimization Problem
children.description: Optimization problem in AI which involves finding the best solution from all feasible solutions, given a set of constraints and an objective to achieve or optimize.

children.name: Search Optimization
children.title: Search Optimization
children.description: Process of enhancing algorithms' ability to efficiently search for the most optimal solution in a potentially vast solution space.

children.name: Training Cost
children.title: Training Cost
children.description: Quantifies the resources required to develop AI models, including computational expenses, energy consumption, and human expertise.

children.name: Advanced AI Techniques
children.title: Advanced AI Techniques
children.description: Sophisticated methodologies extending foundational AI concepts to address complex problems.

children.name: Generative Models
children.title: Generative Models
children.description: Algorithms that learn to generate new data samples similar to the training data.

children.name: GAN (Generative Adversarial Network)
children.title: GAN (Generative Adversarial Network)
children.description: Class of AI algorithms used in unsupervised ML, implemented by a system of two neural networks contesting with each other in a game.

children.name: GPT (Generative Pre-Trained Transformer)
children.title: GPT (Generative Pre-Trained Transformer)
children.description: Type of neural network architecture that excels in generating human-like text based on the input it receives.

children.name: VAE (Variational Autoencoders)
children.title: VAE (Variational Autoencoders)
children.description: Class of generative models that use neural networks to encode inputs into a latent space and then decode from this space to reconstruct the input or generate new data that resemble the input data.

children.name: Autoregressive Generation
children.title: Autoregressive Generation
children.description: Method where the prediction of the next output in a sequence is based on the previously generated outputs.

children.name: Diffusion
children.title: Diffusion
children.description: Class of generative models used to create high-quality, diverse samples of data by iteratively adding and then reversing noise.

children.name: NeRF (Neural Radiance Fields)
children.title: NeRF (Neural Radiance Fields)
children.description: Technique for creating high-quality 3D models from a set of 2D images using deep learning.

children.name: Discriminative AI
children.title: Discriminative AI
children.description: Algorithms that learn the boundary between classes of data, focusing on distinguishing between different outputs given an input.

children.name: Discriminator
children.title: Discriminator
children.description: Model that determines the likelihood of a given input being real or fake, typically used in generative adversarial networks (GANs).

children.name: Denoising
children.title: Denoising
children.description: Process of removing noise from data, particularly in the context of images and signals, to enhance the quality of the information.

children.name: Autoencoder
children.title: Autoencoder
children.description: Type of artificial neural network used to learn efficient codings of unlabeled data, typically for the purpose of dimensionality reduction or feature learning.

children.name: Generative
children.title: Generative
children.description: Subset of AI technologies capable of generating new content, ideas, or data that mimic human-like outputs.

children.name: Sampling
children.title: Sampling
children.description: Process of selecting a subset of individuals from a population to estimate characteristics of the whole population.

children.name: Temperature
children.title: Temperature
children.description: Hyperparameter that controls the randomness of predictions by adjusting the probability distribution of the output classes to make the model's predictions more or less deterministic.

children.name: Language and Speech
children.title: Language and Speech
children.description: Technologies that process and understand human language and speech.

children.name: NLU (Natural Language Understanding)
children.title: NLU (Natural Language Understanding)
children.description: Subfield of NLP focused on enabling machines to understand and interpret human language in a way that is both meaningful and contextually relevant.

children.name: LLM (Large Language Model)
children.title: LLM (Large Language Model)
children.description: Advanced AI systems trained on extensive datasets to understand, generate, and interpret human language.

children.name: BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers)
children.title: BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers)
children.description: Deep Learning model for NLP that significantly improves the understanding of context and the meaning of words in sentences by analyzing text bidirectionally.

children.name: ASR (Automatic Speech Recognition)
children.title: ASR (Automatic Speech Recognition)
children.description: Translates spoken language into written text, enabling computers to understand and process human speech.

children.name: TTS (Text-to-Speech)
children.title: TTS (Text-to-Speech)
children.description: Converts written text into spoken voice output, enabling computers to read text aloud.

children.name: Transformer
children.title: Transformer
children.description: Deep learning model architecture designed for handling sequential data, especially effective in natural language processing tasks.

children.name: Attention Mechanisms
children.title: Attention Mechanisms
children.description: Dynamically prioritize certain parts of input data over others, enabling models to focus on relevant information when processing complex data sequences.

children.name: Chain of Thought
children.title: Chain of Thought
children.description: Reasoning method employed in AI that mimics human-like thought processes to solve complex problems by breaking them down into a series of simpler, interconnected steps.

children.name: Word Vector
children.title: Word Vector
children.description: Numerical representations of words that capture their meanings, relationships, and context within a language.

children.name: Token
children.title: Token
children.description: Basic unit of data processed in NLP tasks, representing words, characters, or subwords.

children.name: Prompt Engineering
children.title: Prompt Engineering
children.description: Process of carefully designing input prompts to elicit desired outputs from language models.

children.name: MLM (Masked-Language Modeling)
children.title: MLM (Masked-Language Modeling)
children.description: Training technique where random words in a sentence are replaced with a special token, and the model learns to predict these masked words based on their context.

children.name: Meta Prompt
children.title: Meta Prompt
children.description: AI technique that emphasizes the structural and syntactical framework of prompts to guide models in problem-solving and task execution, prioritizing the "how" of information presentation over the "what."

children.name: MLLMs (Multimodal Large Language Models)
children.title: MLLMs (Multimodal Large Language Models)
children.description: Advanced AI systems capable of understanding and generating information across different forms of data, such as text, images, and audio.

children.name: Speech Processing
children.title: Speech Processing
children.description: Technology that enables computers to recognize, interpret, and generate human speech.

children.name: Context Window
children.title: Context Window
children.description: Predefined span of text surrounding a specific word or phrase that algorithms analyze to determine its meaning, relevance, or relationship with other words.

children.name: Prompt
children.title: Prompt
children.description: User-generated input or question designed to elicit a specific response or output from the model.

children.name: Computer Vision
children.title: Computer Vision
children.description: Methods that enable machines to interpret and understand the visual world.

children.name: Image Recognition
children.title: Image Recognition
children.description: Ability of AI to identify objects, places, people, writing, and actions in images.

children.name: Object Detection
children.title: Object Detection
children.description: Computer vision technique that identifies and locates objects within an image or video frame.

children.name: Semantic Segmentation
children.title: Semantic Segmentation
children.description: Process of partitioning a digital image into multiple segments (sets of pixels) to simplify its representation into something more meaningful and easier to analyze, where each segment corresponds to different objects or parts of objects.

children.name: Image Synthesis
children.title: Image Synthesis
children.description: Use of AI models to generate new, unique images based on learned patterns and features from a dataset.

children.name: VLM (Visual Language Model)
children.title: VLM (Visual Language Model)
children.description: AI models designed to interpret and generate content by integrating visual and textual information, enabling them to perform tasks like image captioning, visual question answering, and more.

children.name: VQA (Visual Question Answering)
children.title: VQA (Visual Question Answering)
children.description: Field of AI where systems are designed to answer questions about visual content, such as images or videos.

children.name: SAM (Segment Anything Model)
children.title: SAM (Segment Anything Model)
children.description: AI model designed for high-precision image segmentation, capable of identifying and delineating every object within an image.

children.name: ITM (Image-Text Matching)
children.title: ITM (Image-Text Matching)
children.description: AI technique that involves automatically identifying correspondences between textual descriptions and visual elements within images.

children.name: ControlNet
children.title: ControlNet
children.description: Neural network architecture designed to add spatial conditioning controls to diffusion models, enabling precise manipulation without altering the original model's integrity.

children.name: Reinforcement Learning
children.title: Reinforcement Learning
children.description: Learning paradigm focused on making sequences of decisions by interacting with an environment.

children.name: DRL (Deep Reinforcement Learning)
children.title: DRL (Deep Reinforcement Learning)
children.description: Combines neural networks with a reinforcement learning framework, enabling AI systems to learn optimal actions through trial and error to maximize a cumulative reward.

children.name: IRL (Inverse Reinforcement Learning)
children.title: IRL (Inverse Reinforcement Learning)
children.description: Technique in which an algorithm learns the underlying reward function of an environment based on observed behavior from an agent, essentially inferring the goals an agent is trying to achieve.

children.name: MPC (Model-Predictive Control)
children.title: MPC (Model-Predictive Control)
children.description: Control algorithm that uses a model of the system to predict future states and optimizes control actions over a future time horizon.

children.name: Multiagent
children.title: Multiagent
children.description: Multiple autonomous entities (agents) interacting in a shared environment, often with cooperative or competitive objectives.

children.name: Adaptive Problem Solving
children.title: Adaptive Problem Solving
children.description: The capacity of AI systems to modify their approaches to problem-solving based on new data, feedback, or changing environments, enhancing their efficiency and effectiveness over time.

children.name: Autonomous Agents
children.title: Autonomous Agents
children.description: Systems capable of independent action in dynamic, unpredictable environments to achieve designated objectives.

children.name: NPC (Non-Player Character)
children.title: NPC (Non-Player Character)
children.description: Character in a virtual environment that operates under AI control, exhibiting behaviors or responses not directed by human players.

children.name: Hierarchical Planning
children.title: Hierarchical Planning
children.description: Approach to solving complex problems by breaking them down into more manageable sub-problems, organizing these into a hierarchy.

children.name: RLHF (Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback)
children.title: RLHF (Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback)
children.description: Technique that combines reinforcement learning (RL) with human feedback to guide the learning process towards desired outcomes.

children.name: Custom Instructions
children.title: Custom Instructions
children.description: Directives or rules provided by users to AI systems, tailoring the AI's responses or behaviors to specific needs or contexts.

children.name: 1-N Systems
children.title: 1-N Systems
children.description: Architectures where one input or controller manages multiple outputs or agents, applicable in fields like neural networks and robotics.

children.name: Data and Compute
children.title: Data and Compute
children.description: Essential resources and infrastructure for training and deploying AI systems.

children.name: Data
children.title: Data
children.description: Collection, processing, and management of datasets for training AI models.

children.name: Dataset
children.title: Dataset
children.description: Collection of related data points organized in a structured format, often used for training and testing machine learning models.

children.name: Data Augmentation
children.title: Data Augmentation
children.description: Techniques used to increase the size and improve the quality of training datasets for machine learning models without collecting new data.

children.name: Synthetic Data Generation
children.title: Synthetic Data Generation
children.description: Creating artificial data programmatically, often used to train ML models where real data is scarce, sensitive, or biased.

children.name: Structured Data
children.title: Structured Data
children.description: Information that is highly organized and formatted in a way that is easily searchable and accessible by computer systems, typically stored in databases.

children.name: Unstructured Data
children.title: Unstructured Data
children.description: Data that lacks a pre-defined format or organization, making it challenging to collect, process, and analyze using conventional database tools.

children.name: Data Mining
children.title: Data Mining
children.description: Extracting valuable information from large datasets to identify patterns, trends, and relationships that may not be immediately apparent.

children.name: Anomaly Detection
children.title: Anomaly Detection
children.description: Process of identifying unusual patterns that deviate from expected behavior, often used to detect fraud, network intrusions, or unusual transactions.

children.name: Dimensionality Reduction
children.title: Dimensionality Reduction
children.description: Process used in ML to reduce the number of input variables or features in a dataset, simplifying models while retaining essential information.

children.name: Feature Extraction
children.title: Feature Extraction
children.description: Process of transforming raw data into a set of features that are more meaningful and informative for a specific task, such as classification or prediction.

children.name: Vectorization
children.title: Vectorization
children.description: Process of converting non-numeric data into numeric format so that it can be used by ML algorithms.

children.name: Feature Importance
children.title: Feature Importance
children.description: Techniques used to identify and rank the significance of input variables (features) in contributing to the predictive power of a ML model.

children.name: Embedding
children.title: Embedding
children.description: Representations of items, like words, sentences, or objects, in a continuous vector space, facilitating their quantitative comparison and manipulation by AI models.

children.name: Noise
children.title: Noise
children.description: Irrelevant or meaningless data in a dataset or unwanted variations in signals that can interfere with the training and performance of AI models.

children.name: GIGO (Garbage In, Garbage Out)
children.title: GIGO (Garbage In, Garbage Out)
children.description: Concept that emphasizes the quality of output is determined by the quality of input data.

children.name: Vector Database
children.title: Vector Database
children.description: Specialized database optimized for storing and querying vectors, which are arrays of numbers representing data in high-dimensional space.

children.name: Joint Embedding Architecture
children.title: Joint Embedding Architecture
children.description: Neural network design that learns to map different forms of data (e.g., images and text) into a shared embedding space, facilitating tasks like cross-modal retrieval and multi-modal representation learning.

children.name: Ontology
children.title: Ontology
children.description: Structured framework that categorizes and organizes information or data into a hierarchy of concepts and relationships, facilitating the sharing and reuse of knowledge across systems and domains.

children.name: Non-Contrastive
children.title: Non-Contrastive
children.description: ML approach that focuses on learning useful representations of data without explicitly contrasting positive examples against negative examples.

children.name: Compute
children.title: Compute
children.description: Computational power and architectures required to support AI model development and deployment.

children.name: GPU (Graphics Processing Unit)
children.title: GPU (Graphics Processing Unit)
children.description: Specialized electronic circuit designed to rapidly manipulate and alter memory to accelerate the creation of images in a frame buffer intended for output to a display device, but widely used in deep learning for its parallel processing capabilities.

children.name: TPU (Tensor Processing Units)
children.title: TPU (Tensor Processing Units)
children.description: Specialized hardware accelerators designed to significantly speed up the calculations required for ML tasks.

children.name: FPGA (Field-Programmable Gate Array)
children.title: FPGA (Field-Programmable Gate Array)
children.description: Type of integrated circuit that can be configured by the customer or designer after manufacturing.

children.name: CUDA (Compute Unified Device Architecture)
children.title: CUDA (Compute Unified Device Architecture)
children.description: Parallel computing platform and application programming interface (API) that allows software developers and software engineers to use a graphics processing unit (GPU) for general purpose processing.

children.name: Exascale
children.title: Exascale
children.description: Computing systems capable of performing at least one exaflop, or a billion billion (quintillion) calculations per second.

children.name: Inference Acceleration
children.title: Inference Acceleration
children.description: Methods and hardware optimizations employed to increase the speed and efficiency of the inference process in machine learning models, particularly neural networks.

children.name: Model Compression
children.title: Model Compression
children.description: Techniques designed to reduce the size of a machine learning model without significantly sacrificing its accuracy.

children.name: Quantization
children.title: Quantization
children.description: Process of reducing the precision of the weights and activations in neural network models to decrease their memory and computational requirements.

children.name: Tensor
children.title: Tensor
children.description: Multi-dimensional array used in mathematics and computer science, serving as a fundamental data structure in neural networks for representing data and parameters.

children.name: Scalar
children.title: Scalar
children.description: Single numerical value, typically representing a quantity or magnitude in mathematical or computational models.

children.name: AI Systems and Applications
children.title: AI Systems and Applications
children.description: Practical implementation and integration of AI technologies in various domains.

children.name: AI Systems
children.title: AI Systems
children.description: Platforms and frameworks that enable the deployment of AI solutions.

children.name: Expert System
children.title: Expert System
children.description: Computer program designed to mimic the decision-making abilities of a human expert in a specific domain.

children.name: Recommendation Systems
children.title: Recommendation Systems
children.description: Algorithms designed to suggest relevant items to users (such as movies, books, products, etc.) based on their preferences and behaviors.

children.name: IR (Information Retrieval)
children.title: IR (Information Retrieval)
children.description: Process of obtaining relevant information from a large repository based on user queries.

children.name: QA (Question Answering)
children.title: QA (Question Answering)
children.description: Field of natural language processing focused on building systems that automatically answer questions posed by humans in a natural language.

children.name: Retrieval-Based (Model)
children.title: Retrieval-Based (Model)
children.description: Algorithms that generate responses by selecting them from a predefined set of responses, based on the input they receive.

children.name: RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation)
children.title: RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation)
children.description: Combines the retrieval of informative documents from a large corpus with the generative capabilities of neural models to enhance language model responses with real-world knowledge.

children.name: Multimodal
children.title: Multimodal
children.description: AI systems or models that can process and understand information from multiple modalities, such as text, images, and sound.

children.name: Neurosymbolic AI
children.title: Neurosymbolic AI
children.description: Integration of neural networks with symbolic AI to create systems that can both understand and manipulate symbols in a manner similar to human cognitive processes.

children.name: Symbolic AI
children.title: Symbolic AI
children.description: Also known as "Good Old-Fashioned AI" (GOFAI), involves the manipulation of symbols to represent problems and compute solutions through rules.

children.name: Cognitive Architecture
children.title: Cognitive Architecture
children.description: A theory or model that outlines the underlying structure and mechanisms of the human mind or AI systems, guiding the integration of various cognitive processes.

children.name: Memory Systems
children.title: Memory Systems
children.description: Mechanisms and structures designed to store, manage, and recall information, enabling machines to learn from past experiences and perform complex tasks.

children.name: Knowledge Graph
children.title: Knowledge Graph
children.description: Organizes and represents data as an interconnected network of entities (such as objects, events, concepts) and their relationships.

children.name: Knowledge Representation
children.title: Knowledge Representation
children.description: Method by which AI systems formalize and utilize the knowledge necessary to solve complex tasks.

children.name: Cognitive Computing
children.title: Cognitive Computing
children.description: Computer systems that simulate human thought processes to solve complex problems.

children.name: Decision Tree
children.title: Decision Tree
children.description: Flowchart-like tree structure where each internal node represents a "test" on an attribute, each branch represents the outcome of the test, and each leaf node represents a class label (decision taken after computing all attributes).

children.name: Classifier
children.title: Classifier
children.description: ML model that categorizes data into predefined classes.

children.name: Clustering
children.title: Clustering
children.description: Unsupervised learning method used to group a set of objects in such a way that objects in the same group (called a cluster) are more similar to each other than to those in other groups.

children.name: Meta-Classifier
children.title: Meta-Classifier
children.description: Algorithm that combines multiple ML models to improve prediction accuracy over individual models.

children.name: Meta-Regressor
children.title: Meta-Regressor
children.description: Type of ensemble learning method that uses the predictions of several base regression models to train a second-level model to make a final prediction.

children.name: DAG (Directed Acyclic Graphs)
children.title: DAG (Directed Acyclic Graphs)
children.description: Type of graph that consists of vertices connected by edges, with the directionality from one vertex to another and no possibility of forming a cycle.

children.name: Graph Theory
children.title: Graph Theory
children.description: Field of mathematics and computer science focusing on the properties of graphs, which are structures made up of vertices (or nodes) connected by edges.

children.name: System Prompt
children.title: System Prompt
children.description: Predefined message or question generated by an AI system to guide or solicit a response from the user.

children.name: Agentic AI Systems
children.title: Agentic AI Systems
children.description: Advanced AI capable of making decisions and taking actions autonomously to achieve specific goals, embodying characteristics of agency and decision-making usually associated with humans or animals.

children.name: AI Applications
children.title: AI Applications
children.description: Technologies to solve specific problems or enhance functionalities in various sectors.

children.name: AV (Autonomous Vehicles)
children.title: AV (Autonomous Vehicles)
children.description: Self-driving cars that combine sensors, algorithms, and software to navigate and drive without human intervention.

children.name: RFM (Robotics Foundational Model)
children.title: RFM (Robotics Foundational Model)
children.description: Base model designed to provide fundamental capabilities or understanding for the development of various robotic systems and applications.

children.name: BCI (Brain Computer Interface)
children.title: BCI (Brain Computer Interface)
children.description: Enables direct communication pathways between the brain and external devices, allowing for control of computers or prosthetics with neural activity.

children.name: HMI (Human-Machine Interface)
children.title: HMI (Human-Machine Interface)
children.description: Hardware or software through which humans interact with machines, facilitating clear and effective communication between humans and computer systems.

children.name: CLI (Command Line Interface)
children.title: CLI (Command Line Interface)
children.description: Text-based user interface used to interact with software or operating systems through commands, rather than graphical elements.

children.name: Co-Pilot
children.title: Co-Pilot
children.description: System designed to assist humans in various tasks by offering suggestions, automating routine tasks, and enhancing decision-making processes.

children.name: NHI (Non-Human Intelligence)
children.title: NHI (Non-Human Intelligence)
children.description: Intelligence systems that operate independently of human intelligence, encompassing a broad range of entities and origins, emphasizing capabilities that may surpass human cognitive processes.

children.name: WBE (Whole Brain Emulation)
children.title: WBE (Whole Brain Emulation)
children.description: Hypothetical process of scanning a biological brain in detail and replicating its state and processes in a computational system to achieve functional and experiential equivalence.

children.name: A-Life (Artificial Life)
children.title: A-Life (Artificial Life)
children.description: Studies the simulation of life processes within computers or synthetic systems to gain insights into biological phenomena.

children.name: Silicon-Based Intelligence
children.title: Silicon-Based Intelligence
children.description: Concept of artificial intelligence systems that operate on silicon-based hardware, contrasting with biological, carbon-based forms of intelligence such as humans.

children.name: LAM (Large Action Model)
children.title: LAM (Large Action Model)
children.description: Advanced AI systems designed to interpret and execute complex tasks by directly modeling human actions within digital applications.

children.name: LMN (Large Nature Model)
children.title: LMN (Large Nature Model)
children.description: Open-source model focused on nature, using a vast, ethically sourced dataset of natural world elements.

children.name: AI Safety and Robustness
children.title: AI Safety and Robustness
children.description: Strategies and methodologies to ensure AI systems operate safely and reliably.

children.name: AI Safety
children.title: AI Safety
children.description: Measures to prevent unintended consequences and ensure AI systems do no harm.

children.name: Explainability
children.title: Explainability
children.description: Ability of a system to transparently convey how it arrived at a decision, making its operations understandable to humans.

children.name: Groundedness
children.title: Groundedness
children.description: Property of language models that ensures their generated content or interpretations are closely tied to or derived from real-world knowledge and contexts.

children.name: Alignment
children.title: Alignment
children.description: Process of ensuring that an AI system's goals and behaviors are consistent with human values and ethics.

children.name: Safety Net
children.title: Safety Net
children.description: Measures, policies, and technologies designed to prevent, detect, and mitigate adverse outcomes or ethical issues stemming from AI systems' operation.

children.name: Capability Control
children.title: Capability Control
children.description: Strategies and mechanisms implemented to ensure that AI systems act within desired limits, preventing them from performing actions that are undesired or harmful to humans.

children.name: Adversarial Instructions
children.title: Adversarial Instructions
children.description: Inputs designed to deceive AI models into making incorrect predictions or decisions, highlighting vulnerabilities in their learning algorithms.

children.name: Prompt Injection
children.title: Prompt Injection
children.description: Technique used to manipulate or influence the behavior of AI models by inserting specific commands or cues into the input prompt.

children.name: Jailbreaking
children.title: Jailbreaking
children.description: Exploiting vulnerabilities in AI systems to bypass restrictions and unlock otherwise inaccessible functionalities.

children.name: Red Teaming
children.title: Red Teaming
children.description: Practice where a team independently challenges a system, project, or policy to identify vulnerabilities, improve security, and test the effectiveness of defenses, often applied in cybersecurity and, increasingly, in AI safety and ethics.

children.name: Effective Accelerationism
children.title: Effective Accelerationism
children.description: Ideology that encourages the rapid advancement of technology, especially AI, to address global challenges and accelerate progress towards a technologically advanced future.

children.name: Intelligence Explosion
children.title: Intelligence Explosion
children.description: Hypothetical scenario where an AI system rapidly improves its own capabilities and intelligence, leading to a superintelligent AI far surpassing human intelligence.

children.name: Recursive Self-Improvement
children.title: Recursive Self-Improvement
children.description: Process by which an AI system iteratively improves itself, enhancing its intelligence and capabilities without human intervention.

children.name: Sovereign AI
children.title: Sovereign AI
children.description: Hypothetical form of AI that operates independently with its own autonomy, potentially possessing the ability to make decisions and take actions without human intervention.

children.name: Uncensored AI
children.title: Uncensored AI
children.description: AI systems that operate without restrictions on the content they generate or the decisions they make.

children.name: AI Effect
children.title: AI Effect
children.description: Phenomenon where once an AI system can perform a task previously thought to require human intelligence, the task is no longer considered to be a benchmark for intelligence.

children.name: TESCREAL
children.title: TESCREAL
children.description: Seven ideologies: Transhumanism, Extropianism, Singularitarianism, Cosmism, Rationalism, Effective Altruism, and Longtermism. They all focus on using technology to improve people’s lives and they are deeply influential among people working on AGI.

children.name: Super Alignment
children.title: Super Alignment
children.description: Theoretical concept in AI, primarily focusing on ensuring that advanced AI systems or AGI align closely with human values and ethics to prevent negative outcomes.

children.name: Robustness and Reliability
children.title: Robustness and Reliability
children.description: Ensuring AI systems perform reliably under a wide range of conditions and resist manipulation.

children.name: XAI (Explainable AI)
children.title: XAI (Explainable AI)
children.description: AI systems designed to provide insights into their behavior and decisions, making them transparent and understandable to humans.

children.name: Interpretability
children.title: Interpretability
children.description: Extent to which a human can understand the cause of a decision made by an AI system.

children.name: Counterfactual Explanations
children.title: Counterfactual Explanations
children.description: Statements or scenarios that explain how a different outcome could have been achieved by altering specific inputs or conditions in an AI system.

children.name: Observability
children.title: Observability
children.description: Capability to monitor and understand the internal states of an AI system through its outputs.

children.name: Model Drift
children.title: Model Drift
children.description: Change in the underlying data patterns that a ML model was trained on, leading to a decrease in the model's accuracy and effectiveness over time.

children.name: Model Drift Minimization
children.title: Model Drift Minimization
children.description: Strategies and methodologies to ensure that a ML model remains accurate and relevant over time as the underlying data changes.

children.name: Catastrophic Forgetting
children.title: Catastrophic Forgetting
children.description: Phenomenon where a neural network forgets previously learned information upon learning new data.

children.name: Generalization
children.title: Generalization
children.description: Ability of a ML model to perform well on new, unseen data that was not included in the training set.

children.name: Hallucination
children.title: Hallucination
children.description: Generation of inaccurate, fabricated, or irrelevant output by a model, not grounded in the input data or reality.

children.name: Stochastic Parrot
children.title: Stochastic Parrot
children.description: Language models that generate text based on probabilistic predictions, often criticized for parroting information without understanding.

children.name: NLD (Neural Lie Detectors)
children.title: NLD (Neural Lie Detectors)
children.description: AI systems designed to identify dishonesty or inconsistencies in the outputs or decisions of other AI models by analyzing their responses or behavior.

children.name: Confidential Computing
children.title: Confidential Computing
children.description: Security measure that protects data in use by performing computation in a hardware-based environment, preventing unauthorized access or visibility even if the system is compromised.

children.name: Differential Privacy
children.title: Differential Privacy
children.description: System for publicly sharing information about a dataset by describing the patterns of groups within the dataset while withholding information about individuals in the dataset.

children.name: PPML (Privacy-Preserving Machine Learning)
children.title: PPML (Privacy-Preserving Machine Learning)
children.description: Techniques that protect user data privacy during the machine learning process, without compromising the utility of the models.

children.name: Federated Learning
children.title: Federated Learning
children.description: ML approach enabling models to be trained across multiple decentralized devices or servers holding local data samples, without exchanging them.

children.name: Black Box
children.title: Black Box
children.description: System or model whose internal workings are not visible or understandable to the user, only the input and output are known.

children.name: Confusion Matrix
children.title: Confusion Matrix
children.description: Table used to evaluate the performance of a classification model by visualizing its true versus predicted values.

children.name: Negative Feedback
children.title: Negative Feedback
children.description: Control mechanism where the output of a system is fed back into the system in a way that counteracts fluctuations from a setpoint, thereby promoting stability.

children.name: Blind Alley
children.title: Blind Alley
children.description: Situation in problem-solving where a path or strategy leads nowhere, offering no further possibilities for progress or solution.

children.name: Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)
children.title: Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)
children.description: The pursuit of AI systems with human-like cognitive abilities across a broad range of tasks.

children.name: AGI Concepts
children.title: AGI Concepts
children.description: Theoretical foundations and conceptual frameworks for understanding and developing AGI.

children.name: Human-Level AI
children.title: Human-Level AI
children.description: AI systems that can perform any intellectual task with the same proficiency as a human being.

children.name: Superintelligence
children.title: Superintelligence
children.description: A form of AI that surpasses the cognitive performance of humans in virtually all domains of interest, including creativity, general wisdom, and problem-solving.

children.name: Overhang
children.title: Overhang
children.description: Disparity between the minimum computation needed for a certain performance level and the actual computation used in training a model, often leading to superior model performance.

children.name: Cognitive Flexibility
children.title: Cognitive Flexibility
children.description: Mental ability to switch between thinking about two different concepts, or to think about multiple concepts simultaneously.

children.name: Cross-Domain Competency
children.title: Cross-Domain Competency
children.description: Ability of an AI system to understand, learn, and apply knowledge and skills across multiple, varied domains or areas of expertise.

children.name: Autonomous Reasoning
children.title: Autonomous Reasoning
children.description: Capacity of AI systems to make independent decisions or draw conclusions based on logic or data without human intervention.

children.name: Autonomous Learning
children.title: Autonomous Learning
children.description: Systems capable of learning and adapting their strategies or knowledge without human intervention, based on their interactions with the environment.

children.name: Universal Learning Algorithms
children.title: Universal Learning Algorithms
children.description: Theoretical frameworks aimed at creating systems capable of learning any task to human-level competency, leveraging principles that could allow for generalization across diverse domains.

children.name: World Model
children.title: World Model
children.description: Internal representation that an AI system uses to simulate the environment it operates in, enabling prediction and decision-making based on those simulations.

children.name: Embodied Intelligence
children.title: Embodied Intelligence
children.description: Intelligence emerging from the physical interaction of an agent with its environment, emphasizing the importance of a body in learning and cognition.

children.name: Computational Creativity
children.title: Computational Creativity
children.description: The study and building of software and algorithms that exhibit behaviors deemed creative in humans, such as generating original artwork, music, or solving problems in unique ways.

children.name: Foundation Model
children.title: Foundation Model
children.description: Type of large-scale pre-trained model that can be adapted to a wide range of tasks without needing to be trained from scratch each time.

children.name: Frontier Models
children.title: Frontier Models
children.description: The most advanced and powerful AI models currently available, pushing the boundaries of AI capabilities towards achieving general intelligence.

children.name: AGI (Artificial General Intelligence)
children.title: AGI (Artificial General Intelligence)
children.description: AI capable of understanding, learning, and applying knowledge across a wide range of tasks, matching or surpassing human intelligence.

children.name: Turing Test
children.title: Turing Test
children.description: Measure of a machine's ability to exhibit intelligent behavior equivalent to, or indistinguishable from, that of a human.

children.name: Machine Understanding
children.title: Machine Understanding
children.description: Capability of AI systems to interpret and comprehend data, text, images, or situations in a manner akin to human understanding.

children.name: Simulation
children.title: Simulation
children.description: Process of creating a digital model of a real-world or theoretical situation to study the behavior and dynamics of systems.

children.name: Reflective Programming
children.title: Reflective Programming
children.description: Programming paradigm that allows a program to inspect and modify its own structure and behavior at runtime.

children.name: AGI Approaches
children.title: AGI Approaches
children.description: Diverse methodologies and strategies aimed at achieving AGI.

children.name: Symbolic AI
children.title: Symbolic AI
children.description: Also known as "Good Old-Fashioned AI" (GOFAI), involves the manipulation of symbols to represent problems and compute solutions through rules.

children.name: Connectionist AI
children.title: Connectionist AI
children.description: Set of computational models in AI that simulate the human brain's network of neurons to process information and learn from data.

children.name: Hybrid AI
children.title: Hybrid AI
children.description: Combines symbolic AI (rule-based systems) and sub-symbolic AI (machine learning) approaches to leverage the strengths of both for more versatile and explainable AI systems.

children.name: Neurosymbolic AI
children.title: Neurosymbolic AI
children.description: Integration of neural networks with symbolic AI to create systems that can both understand and manipulate symbols in a manner similar to human cognitive processes.

children.name: Embodied AI
children.title: Embodied AI
children.description: Integration of AI into physical entities, enabling these systems to interact with the real world through sensory inputs and actions.

children.name: Evolutionary Algorithm
children.title: Evolutionary Algorithm
children.description: Optimization methods inspired by the process of natural selection where potential solutions evolve over generations to optimize a given objective function.

children.name: Autopoiesis
children.title: Autopoiesis
children.description: Systems capable of reproducing and maintaining themselves by regulating their internal environment in response to external conditions.

children.name: Artefactual Autopoiesis
children.title: Artefactual Autopoiesis
children.description: Design and creation of artificial systems capable of self-maintenance and reproduction, mirroring the autopoietic characteristics of living organisms.

children.name: WBE (Whole Brain Emulation)
children.title: WBE (Whole Brain Emulation)
children.description: Hypothetical process of scanning a biological brain in detail and replicating its state and processes in a computational system to achieve functional and experiential equivalence.

children.name: SIMA (Scalable Instructable Multiworld Agent)
children.title: SIMA (Scalable Instructable Multiworld Agent)
children.description: AI agent designed to operate across multiple 3D virtual environments, following natural language instructions to accomplish varied tasks.

children.name: AI Ethics and Governance
children.title: AI Ethics and Governance
children.description: Principles and frameworks guiding the ethical development, deployment, and governance of AI.

children.name: AI Ethics
children.title: AI Ethics
children.description: Moral principles and considerations in the design, development, and deployment of AI technologies.

children.name: Ethical AI
children.title: Ethical AI
children.description: Practice of creating AI technologies that follow clearly defined ethical guidelines and principles to benefit society while minimizing harm.

children.name: Bias and Fairness
children.title: Bias and Fairness
children.description: “Bias and Fairness” is not created yet. Click to create.

children.name: De-Biasing
children.title: De-Biasing
children.description: Methods and practices used to reduce or eliminate biases in AI systems, aiming to make the systems more fair, equitable, and representative of diverse populations.

children.name: Accountability
children.title: Accountability
children.description: “Accountability” is not created yet. Click to create.

children.name: Transparency
children.title: Transparency
children.description: “Transparency” is not created yet. Click to create.

children.name: Privacy
children.title: Privacy
children.description: “Privacy” is not created yet. Click to create.

children.name: Security
children.title: Security
children.description: “Security” is not created yet. Click to create.

children.name: Dual Use
children.title: Dual Use
children.description: Technologies developed for civilian purposes that can also be repurposed for military or malicious applications, highlighting ethical considerations in their development and regulation.

children.name: Dual Use Foundational Model
children.title: Dual Use Foundational Model
children.description: AI systems designed for general purposes that can be adapted for both beneficial and potentially harmful applications.

children.name: Empathic AI
children.title: Empathic AI
children.description: AI systems designed to recognize, understand, and respond to human emotions in a nuanced and contextually appropriate manner.

children.name: Constitutional AI
children.title: Constitutional AI
children.description: Development of foundational principles and regulations that govern the design, deployment, and operation of AI systems to ensure they adhere to ethical standards, human rights, and democratic values.

children.name: AI Governance
children.title: AI Governance
children.description: Policies, regulations, and standards governing the responsible use and development of AI.

children.name: AI Governance
children.title: AI Governance
children.description: Set of policies, principles, and practices that guide the ethical development, deployment, and regulation of artificial intelligence technologies.

children.name: AI Watchdog
children.title: AI Watchdog
children.description: Organizations, frameworks, or systems designed to monitor, regulate, and guide the development and deployment of artificial intelligence technologies to ensure they adhere to ethical standards, legal requirements, and societal expectations.

children.name: Regulation
children.title: Regulation
children.description: “Regulation” is not created yet. Click to create.

children.name: Standards
children.title: Standards
children.description: “Standards” is not created yet. Click to create.

children.name: Auditing
children.title: Auditing
children.description: “Auditing” is not created yet. Click to create.

children.name: Testing
children.title: Testing
children.description: “Testing” is not created yet. Click to create.

children.name: Certification
children.title: Certification
children.description: “Certification” is not created yet. Click to create.

children.name: C2PA (Coalition for Content Provenance and Authenticity)
children.title: C2PA (Coalition for Content Provenance and Authenticity)
children.description: Initiative focused on establishing industry standards for authenticating digital media content to combat misinformation and ensure content provenance.

children.name: Guardrails
children.title: Guardrails
children.description: Principles, policies, and technical measures implemented to ensure AI systems operate safely, ethically, and within regulatory and societal norms.

children.name: HITL (Human-in-the-Loop)
children.title: HITL (Human-in-the-Loop)
children.description: Integration of human judgment into AI systems to improve or guide the decision-making process.

children.name: Orchestration
children.title: Orchestration
children.description: Systematic coordination and management of various models, algorithms, and processes to efficiently execute complex tasks and workflows.

children.name: Steerability
children.title: Steerability
children.description: Ability to intentionally manipulate the output of the network in a specific direction by applying predetermined modifications to its inputs or parameters.

children.name: FHE (Fully Homomorphic Encryption)
children.title: FHE (Fully Homomorphic Encryption)
children.description: Type of encryption that allows computation on ciphertexts, producing an encrypted result that, when decrypted, matches the result of operations performed on the plaintext.

children.name: Centaur
children.title: Centaur
children.description: Collaborative system where humans and AI work together, combining human intuition and expertise with AI's computational power and data processing capabilities.
